##Page 1
#Page1Line1-0#		In a village on the slopes of Mount Kenya in East
#Page1Line1-1#		Africa,| a little girl worked in the fields with
#Page1Line1-2#		her mother.| Her name was Wangari.
#Page1Time1#		11.4
 
##Page 2
#Page2Line1#		Wangari loved being outside.
#Page2Time1#		2.18
#Page2Line2-0#		In her family's food garden| she broke up the soil
#Page2Line2-1#		with her machete.| She pressed tiny seeds into the
#Page2Line2-2#		warm earth.
#Page2Time2#		9.62
 
##Page 3
#Page3Line1-0#		Her favourite time of the day was just after sunset.|
#Page3Line1-1#		When it got too dark to see the plants,| Wangari
#Page3Line1-2#		knew it was time to go home.
#Page3Time1#		9.42
#Page3Line2-0#		She would follow the narrow paths through the
#Page3Line2-1#		fields,| crossing rivers as she went.
#Page3Time2#		5.14
 
##Page 4
#Page4Line1-0#		Wangari was a clever child and couldn't wait to
#Page4Line1-1#		go to school.
#Page4Time1#		3.63
#Page4Line2-0#		Her mother and father wanted her to stay and
#Page4Line2-1#		help them at home.
#Page4Time2#		3.98
#Page4Line3-0#		When she was seven years old,| her big brother
#Page4Line3-1#		persuaded her parents to let her go to school.
#Page4Time3#		5.53
 
##Page 5
#Page5Line1-0#		She liked to learn!| Wangari learnt more and more
#Page5Line1-1#		with every book she read.
#Page5Time1#		5.34
#Page5Line2-0#		She did so well at school that she was invited to
#Page5Line2-1#		study in the United States of America.
#Page5Time2#		7.12
#Page5Line3-0#		Wangari was excited!| She wanted to know more
#Page5Line3-1#		about the world.
#Page5Time3#		4.42
 
##Page 6
#Page6Line1-0#		At the American university Wangari learnt many
#Page6Line1-1#		new things.| She studied plants and how they grow.
#Page6Time1#		8.28
#Page6Line2-0#		And she remembered how she grew:| playing games
#Page6Line2-1#		with her brothers in the shade of the trees in
#Page6Line2-2#		the beautiful Kenyan forests.
#Page6Time2#		8.8
 
##Page 7
#Page7Line1-0#		The more she learnt,| the more she realised that
#Page7Line1-1#		she loved the people of Kenya.| She wanted them
#Page7Line1-2#		to be happy and free.
#Page7Time1#		7.56
#Page7Line2-0#		The more she learnt,| the more she remembered her
#Page7Line2-1#		African home.
#Page7Time2#		3.4
 
##Page 8
#Page8Line1-0#		When she had finished her studies,| she returned
#Page8Line1-1#		to Kenya.
#Page8Time1#		3.7
#Page8Line2-0#		But her country had changed.| Huge farms
#Page8Line2-1#		stretched across the land.| Women had no wood
#Page8Line2-2#		to make cooking fires.| The people were poor
#Page8Line2-3#		and the children were hungry.
#Page8Time2#		13.14
 
##Page 9
#Page9Line1-0#		Wangari knew what to do.| She taught the women
#Page9Line1-1#		how to plant trees from seeds.
#Page9Time1#		5.2
#Page9Line2-0#		The women sold the trees and used the money to
#Page9Line2-1#		look after their families.
#Page9Time2#		4.6
#Page9Line3-0#		The women were very happy.| Wangari had helped
#Page9Line3-1#		them to feel powerful and strong.
#Page9Time3#		6.84
 
##Page 10
#Page10Line1-0#		As time passed,| the new trees grew into forests,
#Page10Line1-1#		and the rivers started flowing again.
#Page10Time1#		6.27
#Page10Line2-0#		Wangari's message spread across Africa.| Today,
#Page10Line2-1#		millions of trees have grown from Wangari's seeds.
#Page10Time2#		7.92
 
##Page 11
#Page11Line1-0#		Wangari had worked hard.| People all over the
#Page11Line1-1#		world took notice,| and gave her a famous prize.
#Page11Time1#		6.86
#Page11Line2-0#		It is called the Nobel Peace Prize,| and she was
#Page11Line2-1#		the first African woman ever to receive it.
#Page11Time2#		5.82
 
##Page 12
#Page12Line1-0#		Wangari died in 2011,|| but we can think of her
#Page12Line1-1#		every time we see a beautiful tree.
#Page12Time1#		6.28
